choices.D: object statistics in the data dictionary

questions.question_text: Which three factors influence the optimizer's choice of an execution plan? (Choose three.)

choices.A: It executes successfully and creates an UNDO tablespace in HR_PDB.
choices.E: It executes successfully but neither tablespace nor the data file is created.
choices.D: It fails and reports an error because the CONTAINER=CURRENT clause is not specified in the command.
choices.B: It falls and reports an error because there can be only one undo tablespace in a CDB.
choices.C: It fails and reports an error because the CONTAINER=ALL clause is not specified in the command.

discussion.content: The correct answer is E (12.1), remember between 12.1 and 12.2, most of the important features are in 12.2

For 12.2 release,
A is correct answer. Because local_undo_enabled parameter allow to create local UNDO in PDB (tested 12.2)

comments.content: Yes, A for 12.2, but E for 12.1

questions.answer_description:
Interesting behavior in 12.1.0.1 DB of creating an undo tablespace in a PDB. With the new Multitenant architecture the undo tablespace resides at the CDB level and PDBs all share the same UNDO tablespace.
When the current container is a PDB, an attempt to create an undo tablespace fails without returning an error.
questions.question_text:
Your multitenant container database (CDB) contains pluggable databases (PDBs), you are connected to the HR_PDB. You execute the following command:
SQL > CREATE UNDO TABLESPACE undotb01
DATAFILE u01/oracle/rddb1/undotbs01.dbf SIZE 60M AUTOEXTEND ON;
What is the result?

choices.C: They are used to gather only missing statistics.
choices.E: They instruct the optimizer to create only column group statistics.
choices.A: They are tied to a specific statement or SQL ID.
choices.D: They are created for a query expression where statistics are missing or the cardinality estimates by the optimizer are incorrect.
choices.F: Improve plan accuracy by persisting both compilation and execution statistics in the SYSAUX tablespace.
choices.B: They instruct the maintenance job to collect missing statistics or perform dynamic sampling to generate a more optimal plan.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about SQL plan directives? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
https://oracle-base.com/articles/12c/sql-plan-directives-12cr1

SQL Plan Directives are one of the functionalities that make up Adaptive Query Optimization in Oracle Database 12c:
-SQL plan directives are like "extra notes" for the optimizer, to remind it that it previously selected a suboptimal plan, typically because of incorrect cardinality estimates
-Unlike SQL profiles, which are statement specific, SQL plan directives are linked to query expressions, so they can be used by several statements containing matching query expressions. 
-Situations like missing histograms or missing extended statistics may result in SQL plan directives being generated.
-Situations like automatic reoptimization may result in SQL plan directives being written to the SGA and later persisted to the SYSAUX tablespace, at which point they can be displayed using the DBA_SQL_PLAN_DIRECTIVES and DBA_SQL_PLAN_DIR_OBJECTS views.

choices.B: The MRKT tablespace may be dropped if it has no contents.
choices.D: No more data files can be added to the tablespace.
choices.E: The relative file number of the tablespace is not stored in rowids for the table rows that are stored in the MRKT tablespace.
choices.A: The MRKT tablespace is created as a small file tablespace, because the file size is less than the minimum required for big file files.
choices.C: Users who were using the old default tablespace will have their default tablespaces changed to the MRKT tablespace.

discussion.content:
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E18283_01/server.112/e17120/tspaces002.htm#:~:text=Creating%20a%20Bigfile%20Tablespace,with%20automatic%20segment%20space%20management.

bigfile tablespace is a tablespace with a single, but very large (up to 4G blocks) datafile.
A bigfile tablespace consists of a single data or temporary file which can be up to 128 TB.

questions.question_text:
In your database, you want to ensure that idle sessions that are blocking active are automatically terminated after a specified period of time.
How would you accomplish this?

choices.C: Enabling resumable timeout for user sessions
choices.D: Decreasing the value of the IDLE_TIME resource limit in the default profile

discussion.content:
B is the answer.

https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADMIN/dbrm.htm#ADMIN027

Limit the amount of time that a session can be idle. This can be further defined to mean only sessions that are blocking other sessions.

Idle Time Limit
You can specify an amount of time that a session can be idle, after which it is terminated. You can also specify a more stringent idle time limit that applies to sessions that are idle and blocking other sessions

It cannot be D because not all the users have the default profil as their profil.
A user can have an other profile as his default profil. So it won't have effect on that user.
So i think the answer is B

comments.content: they key word is session blocking others. D will terminate idle session rather it is blocking or not
